    scRegulocity: Detection of local RNA velocity patterns in embeddings of single-cell RNA-seq data

    scRegulocity: Detection of local RNA velocity patterns in embeddings of single-cell RNA-seq data

    Akdes Serin Harmanci, Arif O Harmanci, Xiaobo Zhou, Benjamin Deneen, Ganesh Rao, Tiemo J. Klisch, Akash J. Patel*

    2022-02-10

    Introduction.Rmd

    scRegulocity integrates RNA velocity estimates with locality information from cell-embedding coordinates.

    scRegulocity focuses on velocity-switching patterns, local patterns where the velocity of nearby cells changes abruptly, as these patterns can be indicative of transitioning cell states. It then annotates velocity-switching patterns with genes and enriched pathways and analyzes and visualizes these patterns at the regulatory-network level by combining the velocity-estimation, pattern-detection, and visualization steps.

    scRegulocity is publicly available from https://github.com/akdess/scRegulocity

    This vignette shows the basic steps for running scRegulocity

    Installing scRegulocity

    scRegulocity is developed under R version 4.1.0

    You can install scRegulocity R package using the following R commands:

    Install dependencies first:

    
source("https://bioconductor.org/biocLite.R")
biocLite(c("RcisTarget", "psych", "amap", "qgraph", "fpc", "dbscan", "circular"))

    For 3.6.2

    BiocManager::install(c("RcisTarget", "psych", "amap", "qgraph", "fpc", "dbscan", "circular"))

    Install scRegulocity R package:

    require(devtools)
install_github("akdess/scRegulocity")

    For quantification of intron/exon read counts download IntrExtract C++ source or binary code from here.

    After downloading source code type the following:

    cd IntrExtract
make clean
make

    The executable is located under directory /bin.

    Input data

    The input to scRegulocity consists of aligned RNA-Seq reads and normalized expression matrix. scRegulocity uses intron/exon read counts and TSNE/UMAP/PCA embeddings for identifying velocity-switching patterns, local patterns where the velocity of nearby cells changes abruptly.

    1. Generation of the intronic and exonic read counts from RNA-Seq BAM files:

    Intronic and exonic read counts is extracted directly from the mapped RNA-Seq reads.

    Step 2. Extract BAF values from RNA-Seq bam files

    gzip -cd ${ANNOTATION_GFF_GZ_FP} | grep -v "tag=PAR" | grep "gene_type=protein_coding;" | awk {'if($1!="chrY" && $1!="chrM" && $3=="exon")print $0'} > annotation_exons.gff
IntrExtract -GENCODE_GTF_2_Interval_per_feature annotation_exons.gff exon gene_id regions.intervals
IntrExtract -compute_single_cell_expression_stats_per_10X_SAM <barcodes> <bam_file> regions.intervals intrex_stats_ST.txt.gz

    barcodes: 10x barcodes intrex_stats_ST.txt.gz: final output

    You can download ANNOTATION_GFF_GZ_FP file from:

    for mouse

    for human

    2. Normalized gene expression data

    The expression values can be normalized using TPM or FPKM or raw. Below is an example normalized gene expression input :

    Each run generally takes about 5-20 minutes.
